facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 6 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 6 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 8th June 1951 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment -and order dated the 8th day of June 1951 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1951.

facts.text: Appellant is a timber merchant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a timber merchant. On 5th February 1930. he obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Bank of India

facts.text: Appellant obtained loan of Rs. 1 lakh from Bank of India on 5th February 1930 on joint security with Mamraj Rambhagat.

anchor.surface_text: On 5th February 1930. he obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Bank of India on the joint security of himself and one Mamraj Rambhagat.

facts.text: Mamraj Rambhagat obtained loan of Rs. 1 lakh from Imperial Bank of India, Bombay on 5th February 1930 on joint security with appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day Mamrai Rambhagat obtained -a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Imperial Bank of India., Bombay on the joint security of himself and the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant paid off his loan of Rs. 1 lakh to Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant paid off his loan of Rs. I lakh to the Bank of India but Mamraj Rambhagat failed to make good the amount

facts.text: Mamraj Rambhagat failed to pay his loan to Imperial Bank of India, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: but Mamraj Rambhagat failed to make good the amount of his loan to the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay.

facts.text: Imperial Bank recovered Rs. 1,00,626 (principal Rs.1 lakh + interest Rs.626) from appellant on 24th March 1930.

anchor.surface_text: This sum of Rs. 1 lakh was realised by the Imperial Bank of India from the appellant with interest thereon of Rs. 626 on 24th March 1930.

facts.text: Mamraj Rambhagat failed in business and his estate went into hands of receivers on 25th April 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Mamraj Rambhagat failed in his business and his estate went into the hands of the receivers on 25th April 1930.

facts.text: Appellant opened ledger account in name of Mamraj Rambhagat and debited Rs. 1,00,626.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant opened a ledger account in the name of Mamraj Rambhagat and the total amount of Rs. 1,00,626, was debited to this account.

facts.text: Appellant received dividends from receivers: Rs.31,446 on 30th October 1930.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant received the dividends from the receivers Rs.31,446 on 30th October 1930, Rs. 9,434 on 25th April 1934

facts.text: Appellant received dividends from receivers: Rs. 9,434 on 25th April 1934.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 9,434 on 25th April 1934 and Rs. 4,716 on 17th May 1938, aggregating to Rs. 45 596

facts.text: Appellant received dividends from receivers: Rs. 4,716 on 17th May 1938.

anchor.surface_text: and Rs. 4,716 on 17th May 1938, aggregating to Rs. 45 596 leaving a balance of Rs. 55,030 unpaid,

facts.text: Total dividends received: Rs. 45,596, leaving balance Rs. 55,030 unpaid.

anchor.surface_text: aggregating to Rs. 45 596 leaving a balance of Rs. 55,030 unpaid, which sum he wrote off as bad debt

facts.text: Appellant wrote off Rs. 55,030 as bad debt in assessment year 1941-42 (account year 1997 Ramnavmi).

anchor.surface_text: which sum he wrote off as bad debt in the assessment year 1941-42  the account year being 1997 Ramnavmi  and claimed

facts.text: Appellant claimed Rs. 55,030 as allowable deduction under section 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed as an allowable deduction under section 10 of the Act. The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding it was capital loss.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding that the said loss was a capital loss, and so did the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner also disallowed the claim.

anchor.surface_text: and so did the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. It was argued on behalf of the appellant before the Appellate Assis- tant Commissioner

facts.text: Appellant argued before Appellate Assistant Commissioner that it was usual custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security from Banks.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant before the Appellate Assis- tant Commissioner that it was the usual custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security from Banks by persons carrying on business.

facts.text: Appellant submitted old pro-notes jointly executed before Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: It was also stated that the appellant used to borrow money on joint security frequently and certain old pro-notes jointly executed were submitted

facts.text: Income Tax Appellate Tribunal allowed the claim of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal taken by the appellant before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, the Tribunal was of the opinion ... and upheld the companytention of the appellant.

facts.text: Tribunal held that custom was accepted by the Department.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in these circumstances held that -the custom was accepted by the Department.

facts.text: At instance of respondent, Tribunal referred question to High Court under section 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal stated a case to the High Court under section 66 1  of the Act

facts.text: Referred question: Whether Rs. 55,030 is allowable as bad debt u/s 10(2)(xi).

anchor.surface_text: and referred the following question for its decision- Whether on the facts found the sum of Rs. 55,030 is allowable as a bad debt under the provisions of section 10 2  xi

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, answered the referred question in the negative. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 8 May 1956 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. May 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This is an appeal with certificate under section 66-A 2

facts.text: No part of the loan taken by Mamraj from Imperial Bank was applied to appellant's business.

facts.text: High Court held loss was capital loss, not business loss.

anchor.surface_text: the loss suffered by the appellant was a capital loss and number a business loss at all.

issues.text: Whether on the facts found the sum of Rs. 55,030 is allowable as a bad debt under the provisions of section 10(2)(xi) of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts found the sum of Rs. 55,030 is allowable as a bad debt under the provisions of section 10 2  xi  of the Indian Income-tax Act

issues.text: whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or was a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for our determination in this appeal is whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or was a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber.

arguments.claim: It was the usual custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security from Banks by persons carrying on business, preferred by Banks and beneficial due to lower interest, and appellant frequently borrowed thus with old pro-notes submitted.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant before the Appellate Assis- tant Commissioner that it was the usual custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security from Banks by persons carrying on business. It was stated that this manner of securing loans on joint security was preferred by the Banks and it was also in the interest of the traders as lower rate of interest was charged, if the loan was on joint security. It was also stated that the appellant used to borrow money on joint security frequently and certain old pro-notes jointly executed were submitted

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ant. If any monies had been borrowed by the appellant in his timber business, they would certainly have been his capital and whatever loss he incurred

arguments.court_reasoning: Custom requires proof of mutuality and reciprocity which was not established; old pronotes relate only to appellant's borrowings, not reciprocal suretyship; solitary instance insufficient.

arguments.claim: Loss allowable as deduction similar to custom among Nattukottai Chettiars to stand surety for one another in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: before the Appellate Assis- tant Commissioner. Reference was made to the case of Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar 1 , where it was held that it was a custom amongst Nattukottai Chettiars to stand surety-for one another for borrowing from Banks for the purpose of lending out at higher rates of interest and that the loss incurred under the agreement of guarantee by the Chettiar firm should be allowed as a deduction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as Chettiar case involved money-lending business with essential mutuality absent here; later Subramanya Pillai confined it to peculiar facts.

arguments.claim: Even if stood surety in course of securing finance for timber business, loss of sum borrowed by another is capital in nature and capital loss.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, however, distinguished the case on facts and held that even though the appellant stood surety for Mamraj Rambhagat in course of securing finance for his business of timber, it was the loss of a sum borrowed by another, the sum borrowed was capital in its nature and the loss suffered by the appellant on account of Mamraj Rambhagats failure to pay was a capital loss.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or  1  1950 18 I.T R. 85. was a trading loss or a bad debt incurr

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that loss was capital as not trading debt of appellant's business.

arguments.claim: AAC did not opine on custom or require proof so custom accepted by Department; no distinction between money-lending and timber business financing; follow Ramaswamy Chettiar; loss allowable.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal taken by the appellant before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, the Tribunal was of the opinion that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had not expressed any opinion in his order as to whether there was such custom or not had he asked the appellant to establish the custom. The Tribunal in these circumstances held that the custom was accepted by the Department. The Tribunal did not see any distinction between the money lending business and timber business which were both financed by this type of borrowing and differing from the Appellate Assistant Commissioner followed the decision in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras V. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar supra ., and came to the conclusion that the loss suffered by standing surety was an allowable loss and upheld the contention of the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: g business of Nattukottai Chettiars. The High Court, therefore, answered the referred question in the negative. Hence this appeal. The sole question f

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal erred on facts and law; custom not accepted, no proof of mutuality.

arguments.claim: Tribunal erred on facts as no part of loan applied to appellant's business so no allowable deduction; under s10(2)(xi) only trading/business debt of appellant's trade allowable; debt not in respect of timber business but standing surety; capital loss not business loss.

anchor.surface_text: The said reference was heard by the High Court and in its judgment the High Court held that the Tribunal had proceeded on an erroneous assumption as to the facts of the case and the application of the money. Since no part of the loan, which had been taken from the Imperial Bank of India by Mamraj Rambhagat on the joint security of himself and the appellant, was applied to the appellants own business, there was no question of an allowable deduction in relation to the business of the appellant. The High Court held that the Tribunal was in error even in law inasmuch as under section 10 2 xi it is only a trading or business debt of the trade or business of the appellant, which could be claimed as a loss and as the debt claimed was not in respect of the business of the appellant,

arguments.court_reasoning: Endorsed the test that debt must be trading debt of the assessee's trade.

arguments.claim: Relying on later decision in Subramanya Pillai, Ramaswamy Chettiar confined to peculiar facts of Nattukottai Chettiar money-lending business, not applicable to other businesses.

anchor.surface_text: which was the business of trading in timber and not of a person carrying on the business of standing surety for other persons, the loss suffered by the appellant was a capital loss and not a business loss at all. Regarding the decision relied upon by the Tribunal, the High Court referred to a later decision in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. R. Subramanya Pillai 1 , which held that the earlier decision must be read as confined to its peculiar facts and not applicable to business other than money lending business of Nattukottai Chettiars.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rest. A businessman companyld procure financial assistance from the Banks on his own, but he would in that case have to pay a higher rate of interest.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed and applied similar analogy to present case.

arguments.claim: Loss treated as trading loss/bad debt via custom among Bombay businessmen to borrow on joint security where standing surety for another is consideration for reciprocal suretyship essential to financing own business.

anchor.surface_text: The manner in which these monies were sought to be connected with the timber business and treated as a trading loss or bad debt of the timber business was by showing that it was the custom amongst the persons carrying business in Bombay to borrow monies from Banks on joint security and if A wanted monies for financing his business, he could do so by asking B to join him as surety, but he could not ask B to join him as such unless he stood surety for B in the loans which B borrowed in his turn from the Bank. A s joining B as surety was thus a consideration for Bs joining A as surety in his transaction with the Bank and, therefore, although no part of the monies borrowed by B came into the business of A,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rying on of As business. The loss incurred by the appellant in the transaction of his joining Mamraj Rambhagat as surety in the loan which Mamraj Ramb

arguments.court_reasoning: Mutuality not proved; custom as stated lacks reciprocal element; evidence insufficient.

arguments.claim: Custom as stated before AAC lacks mutuality; procurement of surety does not require reciprocal suretyship; old pronotes insufficient to prove full custom; transaction not part of timber business.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to see what is the exact nature and scope of the custom said to have been accepted by the Department. The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest. A businessman could procure financial assistance from the Banks on his own, but he would in that case have to pay a higher rate of interest. He would have to pay a lower rate of interest if he could procure as surety another businessman, who would be approved by the Bank. This, however, did not mean that mutual accommodation by businessmen was necessarily an ingredient part of that custom.

arguments.claim: Finding by AAC that stood surety in course of securing finance merely records statement, does not establish custom; pronotes only appellant's borrowings, no reciprocity; solitary instance insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant laid particular emphasis on the finding by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that it was in the course of securing finance for the business of timber that he stood surety with Mamraj Rambhagat. This finding merely records the statement of fact, but does not go so far as to establish the custom sought to be relied upon by the appellant. The old pronotes submitted by the appellant before the, Appellate Assistant Commissioner merely related to his own transactions, where he had been joined by others as surety and did not establish that the others had been similarly accommodated by him in the matters of loans which they had in their turn procured from the Banks. The solitary instance of the appellants having joined Mamraj Rambhagat in the transaction in question could not be sufficient to establish the custom sought to be relied upon by him

arguments.claim: Chettiar custom involved mutuality essential to money-lending; absent here; distinguished in Subramanya Pillai as confined to peculiar facts not applicable to other businesses.

anchor.surface_text: The custom among the Nattukottai Chettiars held proved in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar supra was that they stood surety for one another, when they borrowed from Banks for the purpose of lending out at higher rates of interest. It was, moreover, an essential element in the carrying on of a money lenders business that money, which Was thus lent out should be procured and that could not be done unless it was borrowed on the joint security of Nattukottai Chettiars, who stood surety for one another. ... It is significant to note that this case was distinguished by the learned Judges of the Madras High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras V. S. B. Subramanya Pillai supra , where it was held that that decision must be confined to its own peculiar facts and does not apply to businesses other than Nattukottai Chetty money lending business.

arguments.claim: Subramanya Pillai analogous: assessee bookseller joint borrowed, repaid other's share, claimed deduction; held not allowable under s10(2)(xi)/(xv) or business loss.

anchor.surface_text: In that case the assessee was a bookseller, who borrowed from time to time jointly with one L a sum of Rs. 16,200 out of which the assessee took a sum of Rs. 10,450 for his business needs and L took the balance. The joint borrowing was necessitated by the business needs of both the borrowers and by the insistence of money lenders, who required the joint security of the two persons. L failed in his business and the assessee had to repay the creditors the whole of the joint borrowing. ... It was held that the assessee was not entitled to deduct these sums in the computation of his business profit either under section 10 2 xi or section 10 2 xv or as business loss. This case furnishes the proper analogy to the present case and points to the right conclusion in regard to the claim of the appellant.

arguments.claim: Debt must be trading debt of the trade whose profits computed; here not as assessee timber merchant not in surety business or money-lender; even habitual suretyship would make loss capital not business.

anchor.surface_text: The following passage from the judgment of the learned C. J. under appeal correctly sums up, in our opinion, the whole position- The debt must therefore be one which can properly be called a trading debt and a debt of the trade, the profits of which are being computed. Judged by that test, it is difficult to see how The debt in the present case can be said to be a debt in respect of the business of the assessee. The assessee is not a person carrying on a business of standing surety for other persons. Nor is he a money-lender. He is simply a timber-merchant.
The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding that the said loss was a capital loss, and so did the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the earlier decision must be read as companyfined to its peculiar facts and number applicable to business other than money lending business of Nattuk

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court held it was capital loss not trading loss or bad debt.

holdings.text: The loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant was a capital loss and not a trading loss or a bad debt incurred in the course of his timber business.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for our determination in this appeal is whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or was a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No part of loan advanced to appellant's business; debt not in respect of timber trade; custom not proved to integrate it as business incident.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 55,030 is not allowable as a bad debt under section 10(2)(xi) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts found the sum of Rs. 55,030 is allowable as a bad debt under the provisions of section 10 2  xi  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only trading or business debt of assessee's trade deductible; here capital loss from surety for another's loan not used in assessee's business.

holdings.text: The alleged custom among Bombay businessmen of borrowing on joint security does not include necessary mutuality or reciprocal suretyship and was not proved.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to see what is the exact nature and scope of the custom said to have been accepted by the Department. The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of old pronotes shows only appellant's borrowings, not reciprocity; AAC finding records statement only; solitary instance insufficient.

holdings.text: The debt claimed was not in respect of the business of the appellant which was trading in timber but a capital loss.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal was in error even in law inasmuch as under section 10 2   xi  it is only a trading. or business debt of the trade or business of the appellant, which could be claimed as a loss and as the debt claimed was not in respect of the business of the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee not in business of standing surety or money-lending; loan proceeds went to co-surety's business.

holdings.text: The assessee was not entitled to deduct the sum under section 10(2)(xi) or section 10(2)(xv) or as business loss.

anchor.surface_text: tion 10  2   xi  or section 10  2   xv  or as business loss. This case furnishes the proper analogy

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to Subramanya Pillai where similar joint borrowing loss not deductible; trading debt test not satisfied.

holdings.text: The debt must be one which can properly be called a trading debt and a debt of the trade the profits of which are being computed.

anchor.surface_text: The following passage from the judgment of the learned C. J. under appeal correctly sums up, in our opinion, the whole position- The debt must therefore be one which can properly be called a trading debt and a debt of the trade, the profits of which are being computed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses High Court's test; assessee timber merchant not surety business; even habitual suretyship yields capital loss.

holdings.text: Even if the assessee was in the habit of standing surety for others, the loss would be a capital loss not business loss.

anchor.surface_text: Even if such, had been the case, any loss suffered by reason of having to pay a debt borrowed for the benefit of another, would have been a capital loss to him and not a business loss at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loss from paying another's debt is capital regardless of frequency unless surety business itself.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for our determination in this appeal is whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or was a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber.

The sole question for our determination in this appeal is whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or was a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to see what is the exact nature and scope of the custom said to have been accepted by the Department. The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest.

It is necessary, therefore, to see what is the exact nature and scope of the custom said to have been accepted by the Department. The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest.

The following passage from the judgment of the learned C. J. under appeal correctly sums up, in our opinion, the whole position- The debt must therefore be one which can properly be called a trading debt and a debt of the trade, the profits of which are being computed.
Even if such, had been the case, any loss suffered by reason of having to pay a debt borrowed for the benefit of another, would have been a capital loss to him and not a business loss at all.
